attributes.title: Stock Verification
attributes.description: A physical stock count of raw materials and finished product was conducted on 8 February 2025 at D2 &D3 branch to verify the accuracy of physical inventory balances against the recorded balances in the SAP System and to determine if stock controls in place were working effectively.
attributes.recommendation:
The branch management strengthens the stock recording, stock taking and stock posting controls to alleviate or minimize the noted variances

The branch should also ensure timely posting of credit notes to avoid distorting the warehouse balances.
attributes.effect:
• Significant variation in white flour is an indication that inventory tracking controls are weak and there is poor coordination between inventory receiving and posting.

  • Bread positive variations are brought up by credit notes for fresh bread that had not been posted and approved at the time of stock this indicates a weak control on timely posting of credit notes.

  • Significant opening balances in crates is an indication that the crates controls are weak which poses a high risk of loss.
attributes.remediation_plan: Planning to have a specific clerk who will only be dealing with credit notes to ensure timely posting and approvals to ensure segregation of duties.

value:
I will do a follow up with supervisors to ensure

system inventory agrees with system balances.

We will ensure consistency in record keeping of crates movement and follow up with sales to ensure minimal opening balances.

· White Flour variances was caused by postings that were done on 31 st January 2025, white flour was not received physically.

·    +Variations is bread is caused by credit notes for fresh that were not yet posted as at the time of stock.

·       The manager is advised to take charge of the store and confirm balances at the end of every shift.

·       The pending credit notes have been posted up to date 9th approval of the same is ongoing.

·       We have a plan to have a specific clerk who will only be dealing with credit notes to ensure timely posting and approvals.We will ensure consistency in record keeping, follow up with sales to ensure less balances.

·       In the prior audit report dated 07th January 2025, stock was as seen below:

ü  Polybags +4,245 Pieces

ü  Utto -14.594. Litres.

ü  Brown flour +15.57 Kgs.

 White flour and White ingredient had variances of +1.202,1.033 and 0.831 respectively

ü  Finished product +371 Loaves Adjusted to -3 pieces after adjusting credit notes.
Current

A physical stock count of raw materials and finished product was conducted on 8 February 2025 at D2 &D3 branch to verify the accuracy of physical inventory balances against the recorded balances in the SAP System and to determine if stock controls in place were working effectively.

Significant variations were noted in White flour and polybags movement.

Audit objective was met.
Operations/Production Department
Ensuring physical stock balances are in agreement with system balances.

attributes.title: Bread weight Check
attributes.description:
·       Weight check for packed bread ready to be dispatched to the market was done to ensure that bread weight was compliant to the standard weights of 400g,600g ,800g and 1.5 kg as per KEBS.

·       Underweight and over weights were noted in the following categories:

Ø  400g CTW/Butter-8% underweight &12% overweight.

Ø  600g CTW/Butter-1% underweight & 28% overweight.

Ø  800 Barrel-36% underweight and 3 % overweight

Ø  1.5 CTW/Butter-13% underweight &3% overweight

Ø  400g Barrel-7% underweight and 28% overweight.

·       Below is the summary of the findings:
attributes.recommendation:
Follow the established quality and weight standards for bread to reduce the occurrences of both underweight and overweight loaves.

A steady and continuous observation of the production flow is necessary to avoid instances of overcooled bread.
attributes.effect: · The presence of both underweight and overweight bread highlighted shortcomings in the enforcement of the established dough weight standards for certain varieties, as well as a failure to monitor the production process effectively, leading to increased chances of bread overcooling.

value:
We will do a follow up by doing frequent spot-checks on weight and will improve on ensure

bread of correct weight is supplied to the market.
We will follow up especially on packing efficiency to reduce bread overcooling, bread weighing will be done frequently to ensure bread of correct weight is sent to the market.

In the previous audit report dating 7 January 2025 the weights were as follows:

  •   400g CTW/Butter-8%

  • 600g CTW/Butter-23%.

  • 800 Barrel-11%

  •   1.5 CTW/Butter-11%.
Current

A physical stock count of raw materials and finished product was conducted on 8 February 2025 at D2 &D3 branch to verify the accuracy of physical inventory balances against the recorded balances in the SAP System and to determine if stock controls in place were working effectively.
Audit Objective was met.
Operations/Production Department
To determine is bread produced was as per the standard weight of 400g,600g,800g and 1500g as per KEBS weight and meausres requirement.

attributes.title: Bread Damages analysis
attributes.description:
·       A detailed analysis of bread damage levels, both from production and market deformities, was done from January 8th, 2025, to February 8th, 2025, to ensure the branch was following its quality standards.

·       It was noted that:

ü  Production bread damages stood at 0.26% of total production, which exceeded the set limit of 0.2%

ü  Supermarket damages stood at 1.55% of total sales, which was above the set limit of 1% as illustrated in the table below:

Table 3:Production Damages.

NB: The production damages analysis above excludes the oven damages of 79 loaves.

Table 4:Market Damages.
attributes.recommendation: Enhance controls within the production process to ensure bread produced is of good quality thereby minimizing the possibility of excess production and market damages.
attributes.effect: The bread damages went beyond the set thresholds, suggesting a decline in bread quality.
attributes.remediation_plan:
Ensuring bread of good quality is produced  to minimise such instances.

Proper handling of bread

value: On Production damages we will implement on a good flow of production process to ensure excess damages are eliminated. most market damages are due to expiry and a few are deformed.
·       On Production damages we will implement on good flow of production process to ensure excess damages are eliminated. most market damages are due to expiry and a few are deformed.
In the prior audit dated 7th January 2025 it was noted that production damages were 0.296% of the total production while market damages were 1.60% of the total sales.

A detailed analysis of bread damage levels, both from production and market deformities, was done from January 8th, 2025, to February 8th, 2025, to ensure the branch was following its quality standards.
The branch should produce bread of good quality to reduces excess damages.
Operations/Production Department
To determine if Production damages and market damages are within the allowable threshold of 0.2% and 1% respectively.

attributes.title: Mixing chart analysis
attributes.description:
·       An analysis of both the mixing chart and mixing chart summaries for the period 8 January 2025 to 8 February 2025 was done to determine if the raw materials’ consumption were as per the set BOM and if the set yield and quality standards were achieved for production.

·       We noted the following:

ü  The average yield was 191.15 loaves per bag

ü  Average production was 197.06 bags equivalent to 91.23% of the set target of 216 bags.

ü  Utto units’ consumption to bags of flour ratio was 1:1

                   434 cases of remixes
attributes.recommendation: ·       The branch management to ensure regular servicing and maintenance of machines to mitigate or quickly resolve cases of breakdowns that lead to remixes.
attributes.effect: ·       91.23% of the production target achievement indicated that there was room for improvement.The high number of remixes implies lapses in quality controls within the production process or machine downtime.

value:
·       Branch production capacity is affected by oven breakdown especially in Unit II

·       Remixes were caused by frequent oven breakdowns especially in unit II.

·       Branch production capacity is affected by oven breakdown especially in Unit II

·       Remixes were caused by frequent oven breakdowns especially in unit II.

·       In the prior audit dated 7th January 2025, the following were noted:

ü  Utto usage ratio 100 %.

ü  Average yield 191.15.

ü  Average production of 194.17 bags.

Remixes 962.
Current

An analysis of both the mixing chart and mixing chart summaries for the period 8 January 2025 to 8 February 2025 was done to determine if the raw materials’ consumption were as per the set BOM and if the set yield and quality standards were achieved for production.
Audit objective was met.
Operations/Production Department
To determine if raw materials consumptions were as per the Set BOM and if the set quality standards were achieved for production.

attributes.title: Production efficiency
attributes.description:
·       A review of the branch’s management of human capital resources availed to the production section for the period 8 January 2025 to 8 February 2025 was done to determine if the allocation of production workers was optimal as per the Company’s set standard of 4.3 bags per production worker.

·       We noted that the production efficiency was at 4.33 bags per production worker for the period which surpassed the set standard of 4.3 signifying over-performance.

·       The results were as detailed below:

Table 5: Production efficiency.
attributes.recommendation: The branch management maintains optimal allocation of production workers based on the set standards.
attributes.effect: The branch allocation of resources is at optimal, to be kept up.

value: The branch management maintains optimal allocation of production workers based on the set standards.
Proper allocation of production workers will be maintained.
In the prior audit report dating 08 January 2025 it was noted that   production efficiency of 4.33 bags per production worker.
Current

A review of the branch’s management of human capital resources availed to the production section for the period 8 January 2025 to 8 February 2025 was done to determine if the allocation of production workers was optimal as per the Company’s set standard of 4.3 bags per production worker.
The manager is advised to ensure workers are allocated based Shift production target
Operations/Production Department
To determine is production target of 4.3 was achieved.

attributes.title: Packing Efficiency.
attributes.description:
·       An assessment for a period of 32 days from 8 January 2025 to 8 February 2025 was conducted on the utilization of packers in the slicing section to determine if they were attaining their set standard of 97 crates per packer.

·       It was noted that packing efficiency was at

Table 6: Packing efficiency
attributes.recommendation: The branch management maintains optimal allocation of packers based on the set standards.
attributes.effect: The branch efficiency was below the standard rate ,41 extra workers were hired with a cost implication of Kshs.37,392.
attributes.remediation_plan: Ensuring workers are allocated based production done

value: ·       Packing inefficiencies were caused by slow workers, we will push them to ensure they are achieving their targets.

·       Packing efficiencies were caused by slow workers, we will push them to ensure they are achieving their targets.

·       The manager is advised to ensure workers are allocated based production done.
The previous audit report dated 7th January 2025; it was noted that packing efficiency of 121.68 crates per packer.
Current

An assessment for a period of 32 days from 8 January 2025 to 8 February 2025 was conducted on the utilization of packers in the slicing section to determine if they were attaining their set standard of 97 crates per packer.
Allocation of workers in the packing area should be done as per the prior shift target reduce extra costs incured in hiring extra workers.
Operations/Production Department
To determine if production workers were achieving their set KPI Of 97 crates per worker

attributes.title: Vehicles fuel consumption analysis.
attributes.description:
•  A review was conducted on the branch vehicles’ fuel consumption vis a vis the set standard consumption rate to determine if there was optimal utilization of fuel for the period 8th January 2025 -10 February 2025.
  • It was noted there were Vehicles which had consumed fuel more than the standard rate i.e Savana had consumed extra 20 litres it had a mechanical issue, Hunters 17 litres, Mesora 14.8, Ngong 7.5 L, CBD1 10 Eastland 7.5 Capital 10.8 Litres, Other route vehicles fuel consumption closely matches the standard rate. We also noted that there was tuk tuk for komarok had faulty speedometer for the whole audited period.
attributes.recommendation:
• The vehicles with faulty speedometers to be sent to KAF for repair/replacement

  • Fuel consumption should be allocated based on the standard rates to avoid variations noted.
attributes.effect:
•        The faulty speedometer for Komarok Tuk tuk implied the mileage could not be tracked and therefore needed to be checked and repaired/replaced.

  •        All other vehicles which had variances imply weak controls over fuel management and there is need for improvement.
attributes.remediation_plan: Ensuring fuel allocation is done as per the standard consumption rates

value:
• Excess fuel to be recovered
    We will send a reminder to KAF for repairs of faulty mileage

• Excess fuel to be recovered
    We will send a reminder to KAF for repairs of faulty mileage

• In the previous audit dated 8th January 2025, it was noted that Ngong and Savannah Route vehicles had faulty speedometers and therefore fuel consumption rate for the audit period could not be determined, all other route vehicles fuel consumption was within the set standard.
Current

• A review was conducted on the branch vehicles’ fuel consumption vis a vis the set standard consumption rate to determine if there was optimal utilization of fuel for the period 8th January 2025 -10th February 2025
Fuel allocation should be done as per the Set consumption rates
Operations/Production Department
To determine if fuel allocation was done as per the set Consumption rates and kilometers covered.

attributes.title: Supermarket returns
attributes.description:
An analysis of market damages (Supermarket returns) for the period 08th January 2025 -08th February 2025 was conducted to identify the reasons and magnitude of the returns.

  It was observed that most supermarket bread returns for the audited period totaling to 22,695.75 pieces with a cost implication (22,695.75*53) = Kshs 1,202,874.75 were due to expiry. Naivas was noted to have a significant return-related expiry followed by Quick Mart supermarket as illustrated in the Bar graph

A detailed summary of all customer supermarket returns is illustrated below in the bar graph below.
attributes.recommendation:
We recommend the branch to enhance shelf-life management by rotating stock efficiently to ensure older pieces are sold first.

 We also encourage the sales team to adopt collaborative demand forecasting with the supermarkets to understand their sales trends and orders accordingly to minimize issues overstocking.
attributes.effect: Significant supermarket returns indicate gaps in bread rotation in supermarkets and ordering.

value: Poor ordering, poor product movement.
Poor ordering, poor product movement.
N/A
Current
An analysis of market damages (Supermarket returns) for the period 08th January 2025 -08th February 2025 was conducted to identify the reasons and magnitude of the returns.
There is need to strengthen controls on bread rotation in supermarkets.
Sales Department
To determine the reasons and quantity of  bread returns from supermarkets
